text:
I'm scared of taking money because I heard I can get fired. 

This was a question, amongst MANY that were asked this weekend at a pickleball mixer for the startup community. 

Let's address it head on. Yes, as investors, we design a host of protections and provisions in the definitive documents to safeguard our investment. 

No, we REALLY don't want to run your company. 

A lot of us on the VC end have had operational careers, building across corporates/startups. 

We're here to invest in the next generation of growing companies.

Firing a Founder typically happens in very very extreme scenarios, namely:

1. Ethics violations: Theft, embezzlement, personal enrichment at company expense, gross misconduct etc

The above doesn't leave much room for other solutions. 

2. Co-founder conflict: If there's unresolvable Co-Founder conflict in terms of direction of the company, then investors sometimes have to step in, along with external mediators/guides, to find a solution. This can lead to one of the dissenting Founders parting ways

3. Performance (or lack of): This is a much much rarer case, with investors usually supporting by bringing in talent to support the Founders. If it can't be fixed, then this could lead to an exit

4. Mega growth: Sometimes, the company grows faster than the Founders can keep up. In these cases, it's usually an amicable discussion, since the Founders are some of the largest shareholders. 

Decisions taken here are collaborative, to maximize the returns for all shareholders.

I've covered the most common scenarios I've seen across 13 years of investing and building, chime in with anything I've missed!

We spend 1/3rd of our lives sleeping. 8 hours a day (ideally!). We SHOULD invest in the best mattress money can buy! This is exactly what Priyanka and Harshil (Founders of The Sleep Company) have built a stellar company around.

Having met during their IIM Calcutta days, they married, then followed different professional paths, with Priyanka climbing the corporate ladder to a ‚Çπ1cr+ package with P&G, having managed the P&Ls for brands like Ariel, Tide and Pampers across India, cementing her understanding of retail and distribution and Harshil joined his family business, exporting engineered products globally, giving him a strong grounding in manufacturing and operations.

Post Priyanka giving birth, she suffered severe post partum pain, with no mattress being able to solve the sleep problem. 

She brainstormed with Harshil, and together they engaged Dr Tripathi, a retired DRDO material scientist with 35+ years of experience, to build the best mattress possible. 

After nearly 2 years of R&D (and ‚Çπ1.5 crore of personal savings used), they created their patented SmartGRID technology. 

When they went to market, with a ‚Çπ29,900 mattress (average indian prices at the time were ~‚Çπ10k), even Amazon reps were uncertain this would work.

Retailers blatantly rejected their attempts to place products, asking how much margin they'd get and how long the credit period was, instead of qualitative questions on the product.

From those early hurdles, they've built a business that's close to ~‚Çπ700cr ARR today, with a VERY controlled ~‚Çπ40cr EBIDTA loss.

They've also built across new verticals. I'm a happy user of their standing desk, and am contemplating their work chair since I've seen a LOT of friends using it.

My one observation. As you grow, operational controls tend to get weaker, and this MAKES (or breaks) businesses. 

When I ordered my desk, it was damaged in transit. The team were prompt on sending me a replacement, which was the wrong size. Eventually, the right size was delivered.

However, both the perfectly good wrong sized desk, and the scratched one, are still stuck in my apartment, with no one picking them up despite several messages.

You've built a really good business, tighten the operational controls and it's bound to be great!

By 1920, the guide became a paid publication, and the brothers hired the first Anonymous inspectors.

1 Star: Very good in it's category 
2 Star: Worth a special detour
3 Star: Exceptional enough to be worth the entire journey

Post WWII, the guide resumed in full force, today looked at as one of the most coveted honours in hospitality.

It's Rant day, therefore it's Friday.

Today isn't a traditional rant. 

This week, a lot of Founders asked me what goes into a successful outcome. 

I started with 'Assuming you're an expert in your industry, or building things'.....

Reasons for the above? It's f***ing hard to build something from nothing. 

Things that help? 

1.  Knowing the problem you're solving, and the industry, inside out. Usually takes a LOT of time. 

2. Knowing how to build things. With all due respect to folks who have built, and failed, if you've built and succeeded (sold/IPOd) those lessons are different.

So I've come up with my four points, assuming you know your industry, problem and customer needs;

A. Customers: Pick up the phone and call your ex-colleagues to use you, find new ones, whatever, can you get people to pay you for your solution? 

B. Team: Can you attract the right folks to help you build? BIG make or break indicator. When I'm looking at companies for a funding round, if they know the gaps in their team, and know who they want to hire with that $$$, big green flag

C. Grit: Can you ride the bad times? The times when there's no money in the bank and everything looks BLEAK

D. Luck: Every awesome entrepreneur I've had the privilege to meet acknowledges this. You can do EVERYTHING right, sometimes it's down to luck

text:
Founder: "I'm here to raise 4 crores"
VC: "Why don't you take 50 crores?

Founder: "What am I going to do with this money? I don't have a plan for it? 
VC: "Well, we start by making your product free!! Then (missing step) and MAGIC!

Founder: "What's the missing step?"
VC: "Look do you want the money or not?"

The above reads like a script from Silicon Valley (the TV show!) or a comedy skit.

Those conversations really happened for many years across India (and global) VC. 

With a dangerous trend towards 'mega' funds, allocators of capital are effectively creating funds that are fundamentally impossible to return. 

In attempts to generate the monstrous exits needed, these kind of conversations were commonplace.

Be free, scale, burn baby burn. 

Founders who fell into this trap quickly built bloated businesses that couldn't survive without a regular injection of cash, basically money junkies.

Today is a saner day, thankfully, but the mega fund problem still exists, so do those cheques. 

Raise what you need (with a decent safety buffer).

Or get ready to ride a rocket that has no sanity and a VERY large chance to blow

The top 10% of VC has performed very well, but the median has just about returned 1x of capital, after TEN years.

There's a constant stream of messages from folks building SMEs chasing venture funding, which is an absolute mismatch in type of capital required. 

India is a very underserved MSME/SME credit market, due to lack of collateral, credit history and high perceived risk from traditional lenders.

- Understand the value unlocked through credit, whether it's reducing blended power cost (in Aerems example) or improving trade credit terms 

- Build non-financial checks, market history, reputation, length of employee tenure etc

- Develop strong non transactional relationships with the borrowers

text:
It's too early for us. We don't invest at that stage. We come in at growth. Series A, B , C..... L M N O P

I keep seeing Founders in my network bump up against this and get frustrated beyond belief. 

Sharing a few (real) reasons why this comes up:

1. Funds operate on Mandates. When we raise money from investors, it's with the promise that we will invest in X type of company, at Y stage.

Asking us to bend that rule is asking us to BREAK OUR PROMISE to our investors. This can get us fired and sued.

2. We usually write some or most of this mandate on our website, social media channels, LinkedIn bios etc. Go through those, saves a lot of time and pain

3. Riverwalk Holdings (insert any fund name) is a Fund Manager. Within this, we run different Funds. Our first fund focused on Seed-Series A. Our second fund now focuses on Series B. This would be similar-ish across other funds, with tweaks in stage, sector allocation etc happening.

It's important to read the most recent news, instead of pointing out at one old article or website link that says 'Seed to Series B'.

4. Different folks, different strokes. You're pre-revenue, going to a fund that doesn't do pre-revenue as a rule. This is going to lead to failure. 

If you put petrol in a diesel car, do you expect it to move? Same example.

5. Sectoral exposure/fit. You might not fit into the sector focus of the Fund, or they are overexposed in a sector. This is harder to suss out, but once again, biggest cues are the Fund's most recent media.

We're on the lookout too, and we post what we look for.

The above should help streamline fundraising while minimizing pain.

Oh and the final reason? It's just a polite no.

Lenskart's IPO. Love em, hate em or indifferent, odds are you've heard a hundred opinions. 

Overvalued, bigger than the Indian eyewear market, making fools of the public, these are all terms being bandied around.

Before I unpack my thoughts, I'll go back to the original motto of Value Investing (started by Benjamin Graham, best seen in play by Warren Buffett).

Value Investing is buying into an asset that you feel is intrinsically undervalued/priced.

It's notionally what we follow as VCs, except we're valuing the FUTURE POTENTIAL of the business. 

Similarly, yes, loss making / nominally profitable startups have been allowed to list, which is a sign of a maturing stock market trusting the public to make their own decisions. 

Eternal has given about 175% returns in two years, Ixigo 61% in 1.5 years, Nykaa -33% in 4 years, which tells me clearly that the 2021 madness was still in the air when Nykaa IPOd.

What I focus on at an experiential and fundamental level is: 

- my parents only buy from Lenskart, loving the store experience

- economies of scale on production are immense

- foreign markets have been tapped well, local friends in Singapore, Japan and Dubai have made the switch and share word-of-mouth about the pricing, as well as free fix guarantee

- stellar team in place 

- India's stock market is generally overvalued, but that's not changing because of capital controls

So, good deal at today's numbers? Probably no, but it's a stock I'm happy to hold as it grows into the number.

JUST SAY NO! It's not Friday but here's a mini rant anyway. 

Humans are bad at saying two things, Yes and No. 

There's a ton of research around this, I'm simplifying it into a few reasons:

- We (mostly) want to be liked. Saying No hurts this.
- Saying either Yes or No closes a door. Usually saying Yes to A, is implicitly saying No to B opportunity. Once again, we shy away from losing B
- We hope that by saying nothing or dragging it out, the decision will resolve itself (or stop following up) and that's the end of it

I've faced this across three phases of life, and I'm breaking each one down below:

Sales: You're looking to sell 1 of 2 things. 

1 - Something new. In this case, you're a category creator. Showcasing the value add to the business is critical, if you can win a pilot and show how you're improving efficiency / saving costs / (or the ABSOLUTE best) increasing revenue? 

You've got a sale

2 - Something better (or cheaper). Here, some version of it already exists and is in use. Replacing the incumbent requires you to showcase a HUGE difference from them, whether in cost or results. Enterprises are notoriously unwilling to shift from an incumbent because of the retraining and costs involved.

Startup: I've raised over $300 million (not alone!) across 3 startups I've worked with, and the critical piece here is identifying that one champion, the person who will go to bat for you. This part is VERY VERY hard. You'll hear a hundred Nos before you get one person who'll build your round.

Venture Capital Fund: By far the hardest fundraise I've done for two reasons.

1 - You're competing against the World of Assets. Public equity, derivates, bonds, art, whisky casks (yes), gold, crypto, PE, then VC. All of these are avenues where wealthy folks park assets. 

2 - Many many champions. While a few folks will be a large part of the fund as anchor investors, funds still typically have 40-80 LPs, which means you're running a funnel speaking to 1000s of people, showcasing yourself amongst other Asset classes, then against other Funds.

Across the board, the biggest lesson I've learnt is, a quick No is one of the biggest gifts (after a Yes) you can give the World around you.

Red Bull. Some of us remember late night study sessions, some late night party sessions, for those of us in college ~2005-2015, we remember FREE cans.

While I barely touch the stuff anymore (espresso shots if caffeine is that necessary!), I LOVE the way the brand built and marketed itself.

For those who may not know, Red Bull is originally a Thai drink called Kratik Daeng, sold at roadside stalls, mainly consumed by construction workers, drivers and folks performing hard labour.

In 1984, Dietrich Mateschitz collaborated with the drink's Founder, Chaleo Yoovidhya, adding carbonation to the beverage while preserving the charging bull logo.

Dietrich launched the drink in Austria in 1987, focusing on nightclubs. One of the methods Dietrich used to create virality was dropping crushed cans of Redbull outside some of the hottest clubs in the city, creating a perception that all the 'cool kids' were drinking Red Bull.

Because of it's caffeine and taurine content, for a while, the drink was banned in Hungary, France and Denmark, with no marketing allowed in Germany.

The 'banned item' craze spread through, with folks smuggling cans of Red Bull into other countries for their friends.

Simultaneously, Dietrich channeled a large chunk of the brand's profits towards extreme sports marketing, sponsoring challenges and extreme sport athletes across skiing, snowboarding, skydiving, racing and more.

Today, Redbull makes ~$13 billion dollars, selling in 171 countries, with a ~46% share of the energy drink market they effectively created.

text:
Fundraising for Science Projects versus Fundraising for a Business

I chatted with a Founder yesterday. They were highly technical, with a strong team around them to build in the Biotech space.

They had gone to the market for a fundraise earlier in the year, were rejected and they came to me for advice.

Version 1: Preventative care, focused directly on consumers. 

Rejected by funds. Very clear pushback here on preventative diagnostics and the Indian consumer. Unless you can find a way to bundle it with other tests/services (selling to Diagnostic Labs and Hospitals), very hard.

Version 2: I spent twenty minutes on the call before I paused the Founder and said "You've shared 3 different products you want to build, not told me how you're going to take them to market, how you're going to make money and, MOST IMPORTANTLY, what's your edge?"

After a lot of back and forth questioning, I understood what they were trying to do.

They were approaching this like a PhD research grant, with a 4 year horizon to hit the market, unclear on the proven efficacy (can their test reduce mortality or risk of disease, by what percentage, and compared to what existing test costs)

My feedback: 99% of investors will not understand this, nor will this excite the 1% who do.

When asked for an example of a great pitch, I shared one of my personal portfolio, Lilac Insights.

Referred by the Founders of Wellness Forever, Lilac's pitch, despite being in a complex field, was crystal clear.

'We have licensed one of the best US tests for non invasive pre-natal (before birth) diagnostics. We've also licensed similar tests for oncology (cancer). These tests are genomic, basically testing for mutations in DNA, then our panel of experts can share suggestions on treatment path.

We will sell the tests in bulk to hospitals, so we have very low distribution costs, while assembling the best team of clinical geneticists with us, ensuring competitors will have to settle for lower talent.

Over time, we will use these hospital relationships to sell additional tests, some self developed by us using funding+revenue'

Our goal is to lower the costs of these tests so that more and more of the country can access them'

This pitch? Takes a complex topic and simplifies it (since most investors are NOT biotech grads).

Tells me exactly how they are going to distribute, control costs.

Chosen sectors tell me there's going to be no reluctance for spending, India will spend anything on childbirth and health, and humans generally to treat cancer.

Tells me their edge (best talent), let's me infer a second edge, which is the data and AI uses.

Tells me of the future, leveraging existing distribution to launch more tests, some proprietary.

Folks, ERASE the word 'Startup' and replace it with Business, since that's what you NEED to showcase to investors.

PS: Addressing the inevitable rage rants, YES, India has VERY low amounts of capital for R&D.

#venturecapital #funding

Farming Vs Hunting    |    Retention Vs Acquisition    |   Boring Vs Fun?

Very often, Founders, sales and srowth leads, young professionals, all get caught up in the excitement of NEW. 

Get a NEW lead. A NEW customer. A NEW channel. 

I sat down with all sorts of sales folks (from BigTech like Meta, Google and Stripe to other VCs raising funds) and a few points stand out:

Numero Uno: It is significantly faster and easier to upsell an existing customer, than to go through the Song & Dance of convincing a new one. 

II : To be able to upsell, you MUST build a strong regular cadence with your customers. Ideally with one core Person In Charge / Relationship Manager (PIC/RM), along with contact points for other support (technical, legal).

The ideal from US bigtech perspective (for large clients mind you) is weekly soft touches (hey everything ok?), monthly scheduled calls (intro new feature) and quarterly business reviews. In a QBR, you compile data, showcasing their usage, highlighting any changes you feel could benefit their business (using your products of course).

Trois : Existing customers are your BEST sources of new features, they will help build your product pipeline. Identify the power users, folks who LOVE your product. Asana has done a brilliant job with this, creating Asana Ambassadors within customer orgs.

2¬≤ : Here's where you can use a level of 'free' or a discount without hurting your brand. Offering an existing client a 3 month trial of a new feature, or a 1 year discount on the latest product you've launched, allows you to test and upsell without hurting your pricing power for new customers.

This doesn't mean you stop looking for new customers! But it's important to prioritize, focusing on retention + upselling before chasing growth

text:
Negotiation. It's a skillset that we all use, on a daily basis, from our personal to our professional lives.

It's inherently driven by one of my favourite economic theories, Ricardo's Comparative Advantage.

Do what you're best at, and purchase/hire skillsets you aren't the best at / don't enjoy doing.

My earliest use of negotiation was in boarding school. 

You're meant to learn to make your bed, clean your cupboard and generally be tidy (at an age when a lot of folks still have parents helping with this).

An admission, I'm quite messy, and HATE tidying up.

In school, I was, thankfully, fairly bright and good at writing.

What ensued was the perfect barter system, with me tutoring my batchmates, and helping them write essays/papers, in exchange for my bed and cupboard remaining spotless (my parents couldn't figure out how I never picked up these skills after years of boarding school!).

Over time, I've enjoyed learning about negotiation from wonderful books and masterclasses, one of my favourites being Never Split the Difference, by Chris Voss.

Three key lessons I've learnt:

1. Define a breakpoint - This is a point where you'll either accept what's on offer, or walk away. Don't waste time and energy beyond this

2. Human Problem - The world IS NOT RATIONAL. Humans are emotional beings, and often, understanding the human element in a transaction can be the make or break difference.

3. Win Together - The VERY BEST deals are where both parties benefit. Reframe your negotiation to show how it benefits the other side, and suddenly, you're on the same side.

What do I need to raise a round? Who are folks who invest?

Perennial questions I get asked so thought I'd take a stab at answering them, in reverse order.

If you're looking for a pre-seed round, GOOGLE IT! Reaching out to me, when it's CLEARLY mentioned in my bio that we are focused on Series B currently, shows me you're brain dead/have done zero research or both.

VC funds spend time, effort and money in publicizing our thesis, writing LONG blogs on the stages and sectors we invest it, trumpeting it across media.

Do give it a cursory glance if you're looking to raise.

The more pertinent place where folks need help, what do I need to raise a round? Fair question. 

Breaking this down (personal views mind you):

Fundraising is a balance between Revenue and Story (read History).

If you have zero revenue? Bring a great story. 

Why am I building this? Because I was at XYZ big companies, noticed the ABC process was broken, have validated this with colleagues and managers across the industry, have my first 3 paid pilots in progress.

BOOOM. You're probably raising a round. (and YES, odds are to get to those positions, there's a strong academic background).

No Story? Bring numbers that can't be ignored.

Some rough guidelines - 

Pre-seed: This is a fairly new concept, All in Capital, ZeroPearl, A Junior VC, Eximius, Mars Shot, great folks to talk to.

No real rules here, can be zero revenue as well, though some helps. Anything up to ‚Çπ30-40 lakhs a month.

Seed: This has ranges. Yes, there are bigger $3-5 million (‚Çπ24-40 crore) rounds. Odds are, you don't qualify. This requires a second time founder (exit of AT LEAST ‚Çπ25 crore, not I built and failed, now building again), or STRONG corporate experience, along with good numbers (‚Çπ50 lakh to ~1.5 crore / month)

Series A: Rounds of $3-10 million, requires you to showcase basic product-market fit, revenue numbers between ‚Çπ1 to ‚Çπ3 crore

Series B: Rounds of $5-20 million. By now, funds are evaluating your ability to scale. Your core customers should be identified, with strong retention trends. The core evaluation here is, can this investment propel you to an inflection point of growth, creating a new product line or expanding into new markets.

Series C and onwards: Rounds mushroom from here, tweaked to give you 24+ months of runway, with a buffer. Rounds are largely dictated by two things.
Your business plan + FOMO in the market.

Note: All of the above doesn't apply to deeptech / biotech.

Folks who had barely/never invested before, including large family offices (surprising right?) suddenly woke up and dived headfirst into public equities, assuming there was only one way to go. UP.

For a lot of people, this year has been a shocker. Markets can lie flat? Sectors can go down? 

Especially given the stellar performances from Korea, Germany, Japan and China's indexes.

Once Bitten, Twice Shy: Venture Capital returns for Investors in Funds aren't equal. 

Based on Prequin Data, the top 10% of VC firms returned over 35% IRR (~3.2x MOIC) across 2015 to 2025.

The next 10% returned around 24% (~2.4x MOIC).

After that, it steadily declines down to ~1x MOIC, which means, 0 returns, but capital was given back.

(anyone confused about time period vs MOIC, should remember VC funds return capital from ~year 5 onwards, and drawdown across a 3-4 year period).

Yes, returns are HEAVILY skewed towards the top. Which is where selection of Fund Managers becomes critical. 

How are they getting into the best companies, what's their right to EXIST, forget WIN. 

I Wanna Do Direct!: The flavour of the month amongst some of the younger family offices I've had chats with is they have jumped into pre-IPO, late stage investments.

The reality of the situation? Unless you're buying out the Seed stage investors, if a growth investor is selling you part of their shareholding? They have access to WAY more information than you do about the company.

I've met some amazing offices that have set up strong internal teams, using Fund investments to identify great companies, then double down with Direct investments, often leveraging Fund pro-rata rights

Overall, VC/PE investments should be looked at as part of an overall asset allocation, with a balance between risk & return.

It's rant time, therefore it's Friday! A really important topic, Deposits/Advances ARE NOT Revenue!

This is a critical mistake a lot of companies make while scaling and it's a very optimistic Founder error. 

Showcasing via a few examples. 

You're a SaaS company that's got a client who's signed up for an annual plan, BUT you have a cancellation + refund option, let's say 1 month's fee as charges. 

A client pays you for a year. 

How do you record revenue in your MIS, AND how do you manage the money? 

It's really really tempting to recognise the full amount (that way mean VCs looking for ARR see a big number) as well as treat the entire amount as earned, therefore spendable.

I get it. But if you're looking to build with a real customer focus (also Ethics), it's best to keep that cash in a separate account. 

Recognise revenue on a straight line monthly basis. 

That way, if a customer cancels, you can refund immediately instead of being caught with pants down.

Similarly, you're a housing/furniture/electronics company. Client pays you a deposit. 

Over time, that's a meaty amount of capital sitting in your account. 

DO NOT use it. Ok, use ~8% of it (one month forward), to be on the prudent side. 

I've seen complaints recently against a host of companies unable to pay back a few thousand rupees of customer deposit. 

This will MURDER your credibility. Not to mention, if you eventually wind up (which happens in startup world), you're honouring your customer trust by returning their deposits.

Distribution beats Product, 9 times out of 10.

I was in Surakarta, Indonesia, a tiny town in the center of the country, for work.

It's a manufacturing hub, and we were there to meet one of the country's largest textile manufacturers.

They hosted a dinner for us, inviting friends who also ran factories in the region. 

I was placed next to a gentleman who manufactured sweets (name hidden on request). 

He had build his empire after identifying a simple concept. 

At Warungs (Indonesia's kiranas/neighbourhood stores), apart from some very specific sweets, most sat mixed together in a giant jar and were given out instead of loose change after a purchase.

Neither the buyer, nor the shopkeeper were very concerned on the brand, just handing out a mix from the giant jar. 

Our story hero then observed that most sweet brands did a round every 10-14 days, adding some sweets into the jar. 

He realises if he simply does a refill round every 5 days (not more, that's getting greedy enough to be noticed), he would end up with a much higher sales throughput .

He built an entire empire around this. 

There's another important lesson here though, that business? No longer exists 

With the advent of digital payments, an under the radar casualty has been sweets sales

Eat your frog first. üê∏

One of my favorite to-do list philosophies is that you should tackle your hardest, most undesirable task at the start of each day. Maybe it's hard, maybe it makes you uncomfortable, or maybe it's just something you've been putting off for weeks. That's your frog.

The idea comes from a quote attributed to Mark Twain: ‚ÄúIf it's your job to eat a frog, it's best to do it first thing in the morning. And if it's your job to eat two frogs, it's best to eat the biggest one first."

‚ÄãSo if you want to be more productive, find that task and do it first. Not only do you get it out of the way, but you feel energized for the rest of the day. Even if you accomplish nothing else, you tackled the hardest thing when you had the most mental energy.

‚ÄãSome people prefer building momentum with easy wins first‚Äîand that‚Äôs another great tactic‚Äîbut for me, the frog method is so much more effective.

‚ÄãI have a column in my Coda to-do list called ‚Äúfrog‚Äù with a little frog emoji next to the task. Just identifying it makes a difference; that's the one I put off yesterday, the one that requires extra activation energy today.

The quote finishes with, ‚Äúand nothing worse will happen to you for the rest of the day.‚Äù As gross as this analogy is, it is a great mindset hack.

Friday rant time! Please, please, please, don't max out your credit cards, take on debt or investment that's unsustainable for your family, all in the hopes that if you get an MVP running, you'll magically land VC funding.

Do it if you're looking to build a good profitable business for yourself.

Bose. A household name. And one of the earliest examples of true product obsession, Indian intelligence and American exceptionalism.

Amar Bose was born in Philadelphia, to an Indian Freedom Fighter and an American schoolteacher. 

Growing up, he earned spending money by fixing old radios and other electronics, sparking a love for engineering.

He followed up on this passion, graduating from MIT (bachelors, masters and a doctorate) in electrical engineering.

Now with a successful career, he purchased a high-end stereo system but hated the sound quality, finding it 'flat'. 

He spent the next decade tinkering around, till he released his first product, the 2201 speaker.

It ignored MANY conventional rules in sound design, leading to critics slamming the product.

BUT .... People LOVED it. The sound quality was revolutionary, making customers feel like there was a concert going on in their house.

Not content with this innovation, Bose went on to pioneer the first active noise cancellation, enjoyed by many of us on the move today.

The company went on to build RideActive suspension systems for trucks, leading to lower cabin noise and disturbance, along with deep research into the field of acoustics.

Bose famously said "I would have been fired a hundred times at a company run by¬†MBAs. But I never went into business to make money. I went into business so that I could do interesting things that hadn't been done before".

Product obsession and customer-centricity, along with a DEEP passion for Sound, led to the Bose we know and love today

A cautionary tale. It's not all Sunshine and Rainbows.

As an investor, it's in my best interest for more people to build companies.

As an Indian, it's in all our best interest for more people to build companies.

As someone who's helped build a few companies, one blew up, one had a tiny outcome, one's growing but at a normal (not VC return) pace.

The common factor I've seen? Humans are WAY too optimistic.

The reality? Over 90% of ventures born, fail. I say ventures because ANYONE, starting ANYTHING, is a venture. Ignore the sexy word, startup.

There are NO safety nets. If you pour your own money in and it fails, that money is gone.

You WILL NOT be compensated at your previous level in the Early Stages.

If you bootstrap, you eat what you kill. It's your choice how to use profits to reinvest in the business or take home.

If you take funding, despite what many armchair warriors comment on, NO investor is letting you draw your previous BigCorp compensation. This is truth.

So before taking the plunge, factor in your liabilities. Your responsibilities. 

Someone who's solely supporting a few people in their family? Bad idea.

Either make the leap young, after 2-4 years of work ex, when responsibilities are low and bouncing back into the workforce is easy.

Or do it mid-career, once you've built up savings to cushion you, ideally with an earning spouse so there's income coming into the household.

text:
Not all solutions are created equal. 

A good solution's most important feature? It solves a deep, critical problem, in a hard to replace/replicate way. 

I've seen this happen often. 

Folks have a passion for entrepreneurship (also called masochism).

They WANT to become a Founder, so start looking for problems to solve.

Not a bad way to go about it, though my personal favourite is when Founders are solving problems they've faced during their careers.

Now in order to make money, the problem you stumble upon should ideally: 

1. Be meaningful: For any company, this means it costs a lot. Everything can be broken down to cost, so time/manhours equals cost. 

2. No clear solution: Folks have tried to apply patchwork fixes but there's no clearcut solution

3. Single point of pain: Ideally, the problem should be departmental/attributable. Someone must be in charge of it 

4. Recurrence: The fix should require your solution constantly

If you've ticked all four boxes above? You've got a solid business. 

It's important to remember that corporate sales cycles have a host of problems. 

You NEED a champion, at a high enough position, with runway in the company, to push your product through the door and into regular use. 

I'm sure every B2B sales person reading this has had a really close conversion, where their SPOC left the company/was transferred etc and the deal went ALL THE WAY back to the beginning.

Family Offices. A new-age term for India, but a mechanism by which European and American families have been protecting and growing wealth consistently for decades.

A big thanks to BCAS - Bombay Chartered Accountants' Society and Kinnari Gandhi for inviting me to be a part of their Family Office summit on Saturday.

Starting off with a fantastic keynote from Rishabh Mariwala, who's family office Sharrp Ventures has played a pivotal role in the Indian startup space, there were fantastic sessions across topics.

I had the pleasure of moderating one with Sachin Tagra, Anupa Tanna Shah, Samir Shah and Rubin Chheda, on the evolution of Family Offices and the advent of new asset classes available, from Public Equities to Private Credit, Venture Capital/Private Equity to Derivatives.

Anupa shared her family's evolution, from creating wealth in Commodities, to preserving and growing it through Real Estate.

Rubin, who runs Neo's  Private Credit fund, showcased the important role Family Office capital holds in supporting the next generation of entrepreneurs through access to debt capital, and how lucrative the space can be.

Sachin manages JSW Ventures, which, similar to Riverwalk, began as a Single Family Office, evolving into a full fledged institutional fund, anchored by the original family, raising a majority of capital from external investors (usually other Family Offices).

Rahul Khanna, CIO of Metro Shoes, explained how it's important to look at post-tax, post-fees returns, while Subeer Monga and Devashish Khanna explained what it takes for FOs to evaluate direct investments.

Subeer, sharing a VC perspective, suggested that FOs should co-invest alongside Funds they've invested in, ideally in sectors they have deep experience in.

Devashish, who runs a Single Family Office, explained that building teams to do direct investments takes significant effort and expense, so it's important for FOs to understand whether they are ready to commit to the cost + time.

One of the resounding commonalities was focusing on good advisors, folks who take a long term approach, instead of making a quick buck by selling every 'sexy' opportunity (pre-IPO rounds anyone?)

author/headline: Principal @ Riverwalk Holdings | Family Office Gateway to Indian Alternatives | TiE CM
text:
Friday Rant time! Please DON'T fall for scamsters & hamsters. 

A Founder pinged me last night, saying there's a UK based family office who's keen to invest in their startup, but needed ¬£30K sent to them before a term sheet can be issued.

For all Founders out there, this is BULL***T! No real investor is asking you to PAY for a term sheet to be issued.

For those who aren't fully familiar, Term sheets are non-binding agreements. They cover all the broad terms that between the Investor, Founders and the Company, broadly around investment terms, control, equity, governance etc.

Folks, there are broadly a few sets of Investors:

Angels - Folks who have enough money to give you ~‚Çπ20 lakhs to ‚Çπ1 crore.
These are typically smaller family business owners, business execs or folks who've sold their companies

Venture Capital Firms - We're all typically SEBI registered (if India based), or registered with the equivalent in whichever country we're domiciled. The partners will have a strong track record, and the fund will typically have one as well. Easy to research.

Family Offices - Definitely an upcoming source of funds, there are broadly three kinds. Very actively managed FOs with large teams (examples include Sharrp Ventures, Capri Global etc). Slightly more understated, representing large family businesses (B2V, Ananta Capital). Very very quiet (not naming for obvious reasons), representing families who have exited their businesses/monetizing land holdings, and are now capital allocators (~‚Çπ5,000Cr+)

Common theme amongst EVERYONE above? We DO NOT CHARGE you for investing. (there will be due diligence costs, but that's to cover external legal and accounting firms, on actuals).

There are some angel networks that do charge, up to 2% to cover expenses is okayish, if you're struggling on a raise they are an option. Once again, DO NOT PAY until successfully raising.

At later stages, investment bankers lend a lot of value, and charge 1-3% for that service, again, ON SUCCESS. This is quite fair.

It's sad but the reality of the world is, there's always more demand for capital than access to it.

In the midst of that desperation, don't let scammers take advantage of you.

Yes I was wrong. While it's important not to let incorrect decisions weigh you down, it's equally important to reflect on what led you to make the decision at the time.

Decisions are typically = Information you have X Current thought process

I usually like evaluating if:
- The decision I made given the information was on point
- Did I have enough accurate information
- Was there anything I could have done better in the evaluation

Apple is one of the few companies on the public side where I was very very wrong. I was an Apple Bear. Anti the company. 

After two years of using a Macbook (still hate the phones :P), I can say I was very wrong.

And a large part of this is due to Apple's decision making tree. Typically, for companies, every major product line has their own teams.

In Apple, there's a Battery team, that looks at ALL products.

Similarly, team for Screens, Chips etc.

I recently had a long conversation with a friend in the Battery team and it's amazing how they make decisions. 

Once they're 80% convinced it's the right call, they get samples for testing, run compatibility checks across product lines, then pull the trigger on ordering.

If they made a mistake, they reevaluate using the framework above.

author/headline: Partner at Kalaari Capital
text:
Dream11's exit from their ‚Çπ358 crore BCCI sponsorship deal - with BCCI waiving penalties due to government regulations - reminded me of a costly lesson I learned during the early IPL mobile rights days.
Back then, we had acquired IPL Mobile Digital rights and partnered with Nokia as our exclusive mobile partner. Everything was going well until legislation banned VAS services overnight. When we rushed to review contracts, I discovered a painful reality - Nokia had ironclad protection clauses for regulatory changes, but I had no such mirror provisions with my licensor.
Nokia walked away clean. I was left holding the bag.
The asymmetry in contract terms taught me that in regulated industries, you're only as protected as your weakest contractual link.
Key takeaways for founders:
üîπ Mirror Your Risk Clauses - If you're giving downstream partners regulatory exit clauses, ensure you have identical protection upstream
üîπ Legislative Force Majeure - In sectors like gaming, telecom, or fintech, standard force majeure isn't enough. You need specific regulatory change provisions
üîπ Don't Bank on Goodwill - Dream11 got lucky with BCCI's understanding. Most contracts won't be this forgiving
üîπ Risk Cascade Analysis - Map how regulatory risks flow through your entire contract chain. One weak link can sink the ship

The Dream11-BCCI situation shows institutional maturity in handling unforeseen regulatory challenges. But as founders, we can't rely on such understanding.
Build your contracts assuming the worst-case scenario - because sometimes it happens.

text:
Friday rant time. Investors don't take risks. Everyone wants Tier-1 background.¬†
Nobody is out there for the little guy.

Sharing a brief breakdown of VC economics (deep dive link in comments).

VC is NOT charity, it's pure financial services. The NUMBER ONE metric we're measured by (for older funds) is DPI, fancy term for how much money you've given back.

1x, shut shop and go home. 2x, better, but still bad. 3x, now you have a reason to live. (for folks wondering how young funds are measured, it's typically MOIC + IRR, basically, how are companies you've invested in performing at present).

Assume a ‚Çπ200 crore seed stage fund. Needs to give back ‚Çπ600 crore at least.
Ignoring fees and expenses, you can invest ‚Çπ10 crore in 20 companies, for 10% each.

Since it's quite clear (Fractal, Zomato, BlueStone, Nykaa) that it takes 12-14 years to IPO a startup in India, you can't wait that long (fund life is 10 years).

So you have to exit to Series C/D investors who WILL want a discount.

Assume 3 rounds of dilution, leaves you with ~5%, 20% discount, so 4% held.

Seed has ~75% mortality rate, so 5 companies left.

These 5 have to get you ‚Çπ600 crore.

At 4% held:

1 company needs to raise at ‚Çπ15000 - Just NOT happening
2 companies raise at ‚Çπ7500 - Still VERY unlikely
3 companies raise at ‚Çπ5000 - Closer
4 companies raise at ‚Çπ3750 - Possible
5 companies raise at ‚Çπ3000 - More possible
^This is also the price Minimalist was acquired by HUL, which was an OUTLIER outcome and first of it's kind for consumer startups.

The above should illustrate how hard the business is.

Hence when funds insist on backing folks with successful exits, strong corporate careers, or absent both, just a great educational background, is maximizing luck.

At Seed, there are two things that swing it for you. I call it Numbers & Story.

If you have a GREAT story (I sold my last company for ‚Çπ500 crores), you can have ~no numbers.

If you have a good story (I was VP Google India), once again, numbers are lower priority.

If you're 22, from a small town college, breaking it down harshly, you NEED numbers.

As an investor, we just DON'T ignore amazing growth. That being said, since this is a (very hard) financial business, we're looking at any and every indicator of possible success.

Experience here helps in two ways:
- Have already made dumb mistakes on OTHER peoples money
- Have a network who will pick up the phone and help you/become first customer

text:
Wealth creation for teams. Great leaders are constantly keeping this at the top of their minds.

Recently hosted a few family business friends over, to cover a range of topics, including wealth diversification, alternative assets etc.

The most critical question from a lot of the new generation is 'how do we retain employees?'

ESOPs/Stock was discussed, but it isn't the ideal solution for a private company, especially folks who aren't walking down an IPO path, as there's no liquidity event for the team to create wealth.

One interesting idea that popped up. 

Every year, whatever profit is earned, after removing what's needed for reinvestment, put a significant portion of that into a 'Pool'. 

This means the Family is giving up a pretty large share of it's profits to this Pool.

The Pool is invested in safer assets (basket of gold, blue-chip MFs etc) so it grows ~12-15%.

If an employee leaves after 1 year, they get 20% of their 'share' of the pool.

If they leave after 5 years, they get 100% of their share, which would have also grown as the profit pool increases + increase in value through investing.

Every year post 5 is treated as a separate cohort (so employee in year 2 will be working towards a separate cohort for exit in year 6).

It's an interesting way to reward all employees for loyalty and retention.

Of course, this doesn't take away from rewards and recognition for the highest performers, but it's an additional sweetener to create wealth for the folks who helped build the company.

Thoughts?

text:
The dangers of data analysis is you can (to an extent) get data to tell you whatever you want, as opposed to a sensible answer. 

This is largely driven by how biased you are when you select datasets, how clean/accurate they are, and how you set up parallels/interpretation.

I came across a post recently showcasing how amazing Mumbai airport is versus two airports the poster saw in Europe.

I'm all for praise where it's due, and our airport has modernized and improved processes in a very big way.

But comparing it to a Copenhagen airport, saying  we process 3x volume, look how good we are, is a bit of BS.

Pick a Dubai or Singapore, 8000 and 7500 flights a week respectively, to our 4000 flights a week, then look at processing times, speed to luggage etc.

One fun fact here is both these airports actively measure and report these statistics (easily found) versus hard-to-find data for Mumbai.

This similar fallacy often happens across businesses, where unless you measure honestly, you end up getting results that you 'want' to hear, as opposed to what you 'need' to hear.

I've once spent a day with portco Founders, ripping apart their unit economics calculations, where even they were shocked to realize an entire SKU line was losing money, where they assumed it was profitable.

What gets measured, gets managed - Peter Drucker (apparently)

What gets measured, can also be gamed - (every Asian)

If a tree falls in the forest but nobody is around, does it make a sound?

While this is an often debated question among philosophy students, late in the evening on a lazy summers day, there's another takeaway to this.

I've met a lot of amazing people and companies in my life. Several have this interesting belief that if you put your head down, build something really amazing, the people will come.

While I have a lot of respect for that silent culture, it's not how the world works.

For those familiar with the story of Tesla Vs Edison, Tesla advocated for AC currents, while Edison was the champion for DC currents.

Today, AC current has become the de facto, proving superior in the VERY long run.

In the short (their lifetime) run? Edison ran rings around Tesla, discrediting AC currents by highlighting electrocution risks etc.

While I'm not an advocate of negative marketing (just a dirty game), positive marketing and brand building are NECESSARY in today's short attention span world.

From Law Firms (who really have a challenge since they can't legally advertise) to Missile Makers, content and brand are becoming a must-have, not an afterthought.

My two cents? The less specialized or subjective you are, the more you need to build a brand.

If you're offering a service/product that many others do, then the best way to retain and grow your client base is by building a rapport, through a brand they relate to.

Luck be a Lady Tonight - One of my favourite Sinatra tracks, and a topic of great  debate and discussion, Luck itself.

I wanted to take a moment and address a couple of realities here.

Privilege is real. Someone born in a country with opportunity versus one without.

Being born healthy versus disabled/sick.

Being born into a family where food and a roof over one's head are a given, not desperately searched for.

That's the first form of luck, and one that's decided for you at birth, one that's genuinely out of your control.

The second form of 'luck' that conventionally breeds jealously or envy, is maximizing serendipity. 

This kind of luck takes effort to create. 

I'll pick an example, pre-placement offers today, even at top Unis, are brutally challenging.

A former analyst of mine (and now good friend) asked for help on how to improve their chances. 

My advice? Maximize the surface area of luck. 

Figure out EVERY event potential recruiters/hiring managers are going to be at for the next six months. 

Beg/borrow/steal the guest list somehow. 

Look up each person's name so you can match the face, for your top 10-20 prospects, read more about them, especially what they've spoken about or written publicly. 

Go up and make conversation at the event, referencing these.

In a market where some of the TOP international MBA schools are unable to place more than half the batch, my friend made it happen.

If you didn't peer at the work under the surface, you'd attribute this to 'luck'.

But there's a tremendous amount of work that goes to make sure someone's at the right place, the right time, and in the right situation to receive that luck.
